articles.headline: On Jet Exteriors, a Parade of Vanilla
articles.snippet: The colorful paint jobs on airplanes have gone the way of free meals and pillows.
articles.abstract: The colorful paint jobs on airplanes have gone the way of free meals and pillows.
articles.lead_paragraph: Airplanes have become just as bland on the outside as they are on the inside.

articles.headline: An Update On Some Columns From 2011
articles.snippet: A columnist talks again with some of the people and companies he wrote about during the year to find out how they’ve fared.
articles.abstract: A columnist talks again with some of the people and companies he wrote about during the year to find out how they’ve fared.
articles.lead_paragraph: Count the T-Mobile lawyers who negotiated a multibillion-dollar breakup fee — Adam Emmerich and Steven Cohen of Wachtell, Lipton Rosen & Katz — and got AT&T to agree to it as among those who will actually deserve their year-end bonuses.

articles.headline: Taking a Chance on the Larry Portfolio
articles.snippet: Named for an investment executive, the portfolio tracks indexes that nearly match the return of the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index, doing so with less than a third of its money in stocks.
articles.abstract: Named for an investment executive, the portfolio tracks indexes that nearly match the return of the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index, doing so with less than a third of its money in stocks.
articles.lead_paragraph: There are so many competing philosophies in the world of investing that most people learn to tune out any conversations on the topic.

articles.headline: Justice Dept. Cites Race in Halting Law Over Voter ID
articles.snippet: The department said a new South Carolina law that would require voters to present photo identification would disproportionately suppress turnout among eligible minority voters.
articles.abstract: The department said a new South Carolina law that would require voters to present photo identification would disproportionately suppress turnout among eligible minority voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department on Friday blocked a new South Carolina law that would require voters to present photo identification, saying the law would disproportionately suppress turnout among eligible minority voters.

articles.headline: Looking Up, Detroit Faces a New Crisis
articles.snippet: A formal state review of Detroit’s books could lead to the appointment of an outside emergency manager to take over the city’s finances.
articles.abstract: A formal state review of Detroit’s books could lead to the appointment of an outside emergency manager to take over the city’s finances.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — For a city that some have declared dead again and again, the talk of late here was of renaissance — of auto industry jobs growing, new companies moving into empty buildings downtown, urban gardens blooming in vacant lots.

articles.headline: Wage Floor Is Increasing in 8 States in New Year
articles.snippet: The minimum wage increases in Arizona, Colorado, Florida, Montana, Ohio, Oregon, Vermont and Washington will be 28 cents to 37 cents an hour.
articles.abstract: The minimum wage increases in Arizona, Colorado, Florida, Montana, Ohio, Oregon, Vermont and Washington will be 28 cents to 37 cents an hour.
articles.lead_paragraph: Eight states will ring in the New Year with a higher minimum wage, under state laws that require wage floors to keep apace with inflation. San Francisco, one of the few cities that sets its own minimum wage above the federal level, is also raising wages for the lowest-paid workers in the new year. It will become the first big city in the country to require companies to pay their workers more than $10 an hour.

articles.headline: Mining Companies Back Friend’s Bid for Senate
articles.snippet: Representative Denny Rehberg of Montana has been an aggressive advocate for the coal and minerals mining industry, a big employer in Montana.
articles.abstract: Representative Denny Rehberg of Montana has been an aggressive advocate for the coal and minerals mining industry, a big employer in Montana.
articles.lead_paragraph: NYE, Mont. — The violation notices keep coming in: broken safety equipment, underground roof collapses, dangerous levels of carbon monoxide — each a hint of the federal enforcement blitz set off more than a year ago by a series of deadly mining accidents across the nation.

articles.headline: Bankruptcy Filing Raises Doubts About a Bond Repayment Pledge
articles.snippet: The era of thinking that municipal bonds were the safest thing after Treasuries might have ended with the bankruptcy filing of Jefferson County, Ala.
articles.abstract: The era of thinking that municipal bonds were the safest thing after Treasuries might have ended with the bankruptcy filing of Jefferson County, Ala.
articles.lead_paragraph: People who own what is considered the safest type of municipal bond may be in for a surprise.

articles.headline: Logging In With a Touch or a Phrase (Anything but a Password)
articles.snippet: Researchers are focusing on making passwords simpler, more secure, even automatic, like a device that can recognize your style of writing or keystroke.
articles.abstract: Researchers are focusing on making passwords simpler, more secure, even automatic, like a device that can recognize your style of writing or keystroke.
articles.lead_paragraph: Passwords are a pain to remember. What if a quick wiggle of five fingers on a screen could log you in instead? Or speaking a simple phrase?

articles.headline: Clash Over Regional Power Spurs Iraq’s Sectarian Rift
articles.snippet: Years of anger and disenfranchisement are driving some largely Sunni provinces to try to wrest more autonomy from Iraq’s Shiite leaders.
articles.abstract: Years of anger and disenfranchisement are driving some largely Sunni provinces to try to wrest more autonomy from Iraq’s Shiite leaders.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAQUBA, Iraq — The governor has fled this uneasy city. Half the members of the provincial council are camped out in northern Iraq, afraid to return to their offices. Peaceful protesters fill the dusty streets, though just days ago angrier crowds blockaded the highways with burning tires and shattered glass.

articles.headline: Vast Rally in Moscow Is a Challenge to Putin’s Power
articles.snippet: Tens of thousands of people demonstrated in Moscow for the second time this month, a victory for activists seeking to forge a burst of energy into a lasting force against Vladimir V. Putin.
articles.abstract: Tens of thousands of people demonstrated in Moscow for the second time this month, a victory for activists seeking to forge a burst of energy into a lasting force against Vladimir V. Putin.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Tens of thousands of citizens converged in Moscow on Saturday for the second huge antigovernment demonstration in a month, an early victory for activists struggling to forge a burst of energy into a political force capable of challenging Vladimir V. Putin’s power.
articles.byline: By Ellen Barry and Michael Schwirtz

articles.headline: New Rules for the Ways We Watch
articles.snippet: The inertia that has kept consumers from bolting from traditional content providers is beginning to erode.
articles.abstract: The inertia that has kept consumers from bolting from traditional content providers is beginning to erode.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the last year, media pundits like me have been running around screaming our heads off about falling skies and collapsing paradigms, and yet as 2011 comes to an end, the sky is still there.

articles.headline: Leadership Lessons From the Shackleton Expedition
articles.snippet: When his ship was stranded for two years, the polar explorer Ernest Shackleton faced compelling leadership decisions that offer many lessons for the business struggles of today.
articles.abstract: When his ship was stranded for two years, the polar explorer Ernest Shackleton faced compelling leadership decisions that offer many lessons for the business struggles of today.
articles.lead_paragraph: A HUNDRED years ago this month, the Norwegian explorer Roald Amundsen and four teammates became the first men to reach the South Pole, arriving in triumph five weeks ahead of Robert Falcon Scott. The Amundsen crew would return safely to its base, but, heartbreakingly, Scott and his four British companions died on the return journey.

articles.headline: Bourbon’s All-American Roar
articles.snippet: Sales of bourbon are rising, helped by premium small-batch and single-barrel products and flavor infusions like honey, cherry and spice. Now distillers are looking to extend their overseas reach.
articles.abstract: Sales of bourbon are rising, helped by premium small-batch and single-barrel products and flavor infusions like honey, cherry and spice. Now distillers are looking to extend their overseas reach.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky.

articles.headline: Foreclosure Relief? Don’t Hold Your Breath
articles.snippet: A new Washington program, intended to help homeowners caught in the mortgage mess, has many moving parts. And foreclosure experts are seeing many flaws.
articles.abstract: A new Washington program, intended to help homeowners caught in the mortgage mess, has many moving parts. And foreclosure experts are seeing many flaws.
articles.lead_paragraph: THROUGHOUT the foreclosure crisis, Washington has done little to help people hang on to their homes. All those programs that were supposed to help — HAMP, HARP, Hope for Homeowners — have mostly failed.

articles.headline: At Harvard, a Master’s in Problem Solving
articles.snippet: Pragmatic, data-driven and hard-working — the person Mitt Romney was in the mid-70s in graduate school is the person he is now, his former classmates say.
articles.abstract: Pragmatic, data-driven and hard-working — the person Mitt Romney was in the mid-70s in graduate school is the person he is now, his former classmates say.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few years after Mitt Romney graduated from Harvard Business School, he returned to share a simple, timeworn lesson in an unusual way.

articles.headline: U.S. Embraces a Low-Key Response to Turmoil in Iraq
articles.snippet: President Obama says he has no intention of sending troops back to Iraq, even if sectarian violence and political upheaval devolve into civil war.
articles.abstract: President Obama says he has no intention of sending troops back to Iraq, even if sectarian violence and political upheaval devolve into civil war.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Iraq erupted in recent days, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. was in constant phone contact with the leaders of the country’s dueling sects. He called the Shiite prime minister and the Sunni speaker of the Parliament on Tuesday, and the Kurdish leader on Thursday, urging them to try to resolve the political crisis.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Thom Shanker

articles.headline: Ruling by Justice Dept. Opens a Door on Online Gambling
articles.snippet: New York officials welcomed a legal opinion removing a big obstacle for states that want to sanction Internet gaming to help fix their budget deficits.
articles.abstract: New York officials welcomed a legal opinion removing a big obstacle for states that want to sanction Internet gaming to help fix their budget deficits.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department has reversed its long-held opposition to many forms of Internet gambling, removing a big legal obstacle for states that want to sanction online gambling to help fix their budget deficits.

articles.headline: Nigerian Group Escalates Violence With Church Attacks
articles.snippet: A series of Christmas Day church bombings, in which 25 people died, appeared to be a coordinated assault by Boko Haram, a radical Islamist sect with suspected training links to Al Qaeda.
articles.abstract: A series of Christmas Day church bombings, in which 25 people died, appeared to be a coordinated assault by Boko Haram, a radical Islamist sect with suspected training links to Al Qaeda.
articles.lead_paragraph: A series of Christmas Day church bombings rocked Nigeria on Sunday in what appeared to be a coordinated assault by a radical Islamist sect with suspected training links to Al Qaeda, raising the sect’s violent antigovernment struggle to a new and more dangerous level that the Nigerian authorities seem powerless to contain. At least 25 people were killed.

articles.headline: A Dispute Over Who Owns a Twitter Account Goes to Court
articles.snippet: A lawsuit filed this summer could answer the growing question of whether a company can claim ownership of an employee’s social media account.
articles.abstract: A lawsuit filed this summer could answer the growing question of whether a company can claim ownership of an employee’s social media account.
articles.lead_paragraph: How much is a tweet worth? And how much does a Twitter follower cost?

articles.headline: A Year of Disappointment at the Movie Box Office
articles.snippet: In the final days of 2011, ticket sales in North America are running about $500 million behind last year, prompting studios to wonder what went wrong.
articles.abstract: In the final days of 2011, ticket sales in North America are running about $500 million behind last year, prompting studios to wonder what went wrong.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — With five days left in 2011, ticket sales in North America are running about $500 million behind last year — despite higher prices — prompting a round of soul searching by studios trying to determine what went wrong and how best to proceed.

articles.headline: In Beck’s Shadow, Rise of ‘The Five’
articles.snippet: “The Five,” a panel of five co-hosts who argue about the day’s top stories, seemed to be a quick fix for Fox News after Glenn Beck’s departure last June, but the show has found its footing.
articles.abstract: “The Five,” a panel of five co-hosts who argue about the day’s top stories, seemed to be a quick fix for Fox News after Glenn Beck’s departure last June, but the show has found its footing.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Fox News and Glenn Beck broke up in June, the network’s chairman, Roger Ailes, knew he could not put any single man or woman in that 5 p.m. time slot, lest he or she be compared to Mr. Beck or be pummeled in the press if the ratings tumbled.

articles.headline: U.S. Firms See Opportunities in Europe’s Woes
articles.snippet: European regulators have ordered banks to raise capital and shrink their balance sheets, leading to the sale of assets to American businesses and financial firms.
articles.abstract: European regulators have ordered banks to raise capital and shrink their balance sheets, leading to the sale of assets to American businesses and financial firms.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Europe struggles with its debt crisis, American businesses and financial firms are swooping in amid the distress, making loans and snapping up assets owned by banks there — from the mortgage on a luxury hotel in Miami Beach to the tallest office building in Dublin.

articles.headline: Cee Lo Strikes Gold, Without a Gold Album
articles.snippet: Cee Lo Green, an entertainer devoted to the Liberace and Elton John school of showmanship, will earn about $20 million this year, and only a fraction of that is from his music.
articles.abstract: Cee Lo Green, an entertainer devoted to the Liberace and Elton John school of showmanship, will earn about $20 million this year, and only a fraction of that is from his music.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ducking through a crowd of tourists at Rockefeller Center, the singer Cee Lo Green took a breather during rehearsals for NBC’s annual tree-lighting concert on Nov. 30. But between a shopping detour at Swarovski Crystal and last-minute talks with the show’s producer, there wasn’t much time to rest.

articles.headline: U.S. Prepares for a Curtailed Relationship With Pakistan
articles.snippet: With the United States facing the reality that its broad security partnership with Pakistan is over, officials are seeking to salvage a more limited counterterrorism alliance.
articles.abstract: With the United States facing the reality that its broad security partnership with Pakistan is over, officials are seeking to salvage a more limited counterterrorism alliance.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — With the United States facing the reality that its broad security partnership with Pakistan is over, American officials are seeking to salvage a more limited counterterrorism alliance that they acknowledge will complicate their ability to launch attacks against extremists and move supplies into Afghanistan.

articles.headline: Crusaders Take Page, and Outfits, From Comics
articles.snippet: Self-cast crime fighters are on the march, but whether they are making the world safer or just weirder remains an open question.
articles.abstract: Self-cast crime fighters are on the march, but whether they are making the world safer or just weirder remains an open question.
articles.lead_paragraph: SALT LAKE CITY — Red Voltage and two of his masked crime-fighting colleagues were approaching an intersection here in Utah’s capital on a recent evening, walking night patrol on foot, when a car suddenly slowed next to them. The night was bitterly cold, laced with a wispy stew of fog that might or might not conceal a thousand dangers. The car’s window rolled down.

articles.headline: Paul Disowns Extremists’ Views but Doesn’t Disavow the Support
articles.snippet: The white supremacists, survivalists and anti-Zionists who have rallied behind Ron Paul’s candidacy have not exactly been warmly welcomed. But he does not disavow their support.
articles.abstract: The white supremacists, survivalists and anti-Zionists who have rallied behind Ron Paul’s candidacy have not exactly been warmly welcomed. But he does not disavow their support.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American Free Press, which markets books like “The Invention of the Jewish People” and “March of the Titans: A History of the White Race,” is urging its subscribers to help it send hundreds of copies of Ron Paul’s collected speeches to voters in New Hampshire. The book, it promises, will “Help Dr. Ron Paul Win the G.O.P. Nomination in 2012!”
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg and Serge F. Kovaleski

articles.headline: Navigating Love and Autism
articles.snippet: For Jack Robison and Kirsten Lindsmith, both of whom fall on the autism spectrum, being in a relationship together has created a unique set of comforts and challenges.
articles.abstract: For Jack Robison and Kirsten Lindsmith, both of whom fall on the autism spectrum, being in a relationship together has created a unique set of comforts and challenges.
articles.lead_paragraph: GREENFIELD, Mass. — The first night they slept entwined on his futon, Jack Robison, 19, who had since childhood thought of himself as “not like the other humans,” regarded Kirsten Lindsmith with undisguised tenderness.

articles.headline: Path Is Cleared for Yemeni Leader to Get Care in U.S.
articles.snippet: The Obama administration has decided in principle to allow President Ali Abdullah Saleh to enter the United States for medical treatment, subject to assurances, officials said.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration has decided in principle to allow President Ali Abdullah Saleh to enter the United States for medical treatment, subject to assurances, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONOLULU — The Obama administration has decided in principle to allow the embattled president of Yemen, Ali Abdullah Saleh, to enter the United States for medical treatment, subject to certain assurances, two administration officials said Monday.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Eric Schmitt
